item.title: Congratulations in Science 2022
item.description: During the aging process, the brain experiences a significant loss of hypocretin (Hcrt)/orexin neurons. The high excitability of aged hypocretin neurons, characterized by depolarization of the resting potential, along with the adaptive upregulation of prepro-Hcrt mRNA expression, leads to fragmented sleep during aging. The aged Hcrt neurons with high excitability express a reduced M-current mediated by KCNQ2/3 channels, and the decreased expression of KCNQ2 impairs the neuronâ€™s repolarization capacity.
